places.generalDescription: Perched atop the Neel Parvat in the Shivalik Hills, Shri Maa Chandi Devi Temple is a historic Hindu pilgrimage site with a rich legacy. Built in 1929, it is believed to house an ancient idol of the goddess dating back to the 8th century. The temple attracts devotees year-round and is known as a Siddha Peetha, where worshippers seek fulfillment of their desires.

sources.snippet: Chandi Devi Temple is another Siddh Peeth dedicated to Goddess Chandi – a form of Goddess Durga and is visited by thousands of devotees to get their wishes fulfilled. This temple is situated atop the Shivalik Hills’ Neel Parvat, which was the mythological battleground where the goddess killed demons Chand-Mund and later, Shumbh-Nishumbh. The temple is believed to have been constructed by the Kashmir King Suchan Singh while the idol was established in the 8 th century by Adi Shankaracharya.

reviews.text:
Visited Shree Ma Chandi Devi Temple on 20th April 2025. To reach the temple, we bought tickets for the ropeway service called Udan Khatola. Tickets were priced at ₹240 per person. It was quite hot that day, but the short ropeway ride - just a few minutes from the bottom to the hilltop - was comfortable and offered beautiful views.

The temple itself has a simple and peaceful architecture, which adds to its charm. However, be prepared for long queues at every step, from the ropeway boarding point to the temple entrance and inside the temple premises. Despite the crowd, the overall experience was spiritually uplifting.

The ropeway is well-managed, and the staff was helpful, but due to the heat and waiting time, it's a good idea to carry water and maybe visit earlier in the day. Overall, a memorable visit to one of Haridwar's most sacred spots!

Chandi devi temple located at hilltop of Neel Parvat was memorable experience. We went by ropeway to enjoy bird's eye view of Haridwar, Ganda river and  surrounding hills. Early Morning Trekking is also good option to enjoy panaramic view.

You can either buy combo of Mansa devi and chandi devi temple the only thing is you should be able to reach both temples on the same day if there's no long queues then it's easy. When we went in 2022 combo charges 324 rs per person while only chandi devi temple ticket charges 195 rs per person.

Temple is clean and well maintained. Temple premises contains idols of lord kali ma, sankat mochan hanuman, Maa Annapurna, Santoshi Maa etc. This siddhpeeth is heavy crowded on festive like Navratri and holiday season. There are waiting halls at each levels and quite nice dining cafe inside and children game area to spend sometime. You'll find beautiful dress photography studies at all places in haridwar rishikesh masoorie.

Chandi Devi Temple is highly revered by devotees as a Siddh Peetha which is a place of worship where desires get fulfilled. It is one of three such Peethas located in Haridwar, the other two being Mansa Devi Temple and Maya Devi Temple.

Goddess Chandi also known as Chandika is the presiding deity of the temple. The story of the origin of Chandika is as follows: Long time ago, the demon kings Shumbha and Nishumbha had captured the kingdom of the god-king of heaven - Indra and thrown the gods from Swarga (heaven). After intense prayers by the gods, a goddess emerged from Parvati. An exceptionally beautiful woman and amazed by her beauty, Shumbha desired to marry her. On being refused, Shumbha sent his demon chiefs Chanda and Munda to kill her. They were killed by goddess Chamunda who originated out of Chandika's anger. Shumbha and Nishumbha then collectively tried to kill Chandika but were instead slain by the goddess. Thereafter, Chandika is said to have rested for a short while at the top of Neel Parvat and later a temple was built here to testify the legend. Also, the two peaks located in the mountain range are called Shumbha and Nishumbha.

reviews.text: Jai Mansa Devi. A beautiful temple located on a hillock overlooking River Ganges, in Haridwar. Take the cable car and enjoy the scenic views enroute. Starting point for the cable car is located at 20 minutes driving time from Harki Pauri. You may also walk up till the base in the same time. The Base is too crowded with long queue for cable car tickets, shops and eateries. Take the cable car and enjoy the scenic views. Have a divine Darshan of Maa Devi and other devtas. Enjoy the experience of shopping enroute. No photography is permitted within the temple.

Firstly pay price then only will be allowed to go near all god and goddess statue. If unable to pay then just see from far away. 4⭐ for scenery view of Mountain . It took only 1 to 1.30 hrs. To complete full trip.

The temple is serene on the top of the hill. We took the ropeway to reach the top. It costs 200 per person for the round trip. We get a glimpse of the city view from the ride that lasts barely 2-3 mins. There is a shoe stand just before the entrance of the temple ... So one need not leave it near any shop and then be forced to buy stuff from them. There is a coconut breaking area at the back... Otherwise all the pooja stuff we buy is dumped into a box. So avoid buying those small red bags for Rs.100. Darshan shall be quick and one will get ample time to see and pray mata ji. On the way back for ropeway users there is a small cafeteria with snacks at affordable prices.
Non consent photography for the pure intent of making money is something I dislike. They should have made this optional.

reviews.text: The temple where Mata sati was born and also the same place where she jumped into the hawan kund, when mahadev is insulted by his father. After listening to this that Mata sati is no more mahadev incarnate veerbhadra one of his most aggressive and powerful entity and command him to kill prajapati daksh,and also command him if any God, Gandharva, army, demi God came up in his way then also kill them but don't stop.. so veerbhadra defeated the whole army and tear them like a piece of paper and killed the prajapati daksh by his single attack and separate his head from his body. After that mahadeb took Mata sati body and roamed in the entire world here and there , and seeing this lord Vishnu start cutting Mata sati body in many parts and each part fallen down on earth and where the all 108 pieces are fall are today's known as shaktipeeth..

Where Divinity Meets Eternity – Daksheswar Mahadev Temple, Kankhal

In the serene heart of Kankhal, Haridwar, lies Daksheswar Mahadev Temple - more than just a temple, it is a place where myth and divinity quietly breathe as one. This sacred site holds deep significance in Hindu mythology, marking the place where King Daksha performed his yajna and where Goddess Sati, overcome with grief and devotion, surrendered herself to the sacred fire.

The temple echoes the divine tale of Lord Shiva's sorrow, the creation of Virbhadra, and the eternal love between Shiva and Sati - a story of cosmic energy, sacrifice, and spiritual union. Even today, the energy here is palpable - peaceful yet deeply powerful.

As you walk through the temple's corridors, you don't just witness devotion… you feel it. The gentle chimes of the bells, the fragrance of incense, and the chants in the air transport you to another realm. It's a place where time slows down, where the heart feels light, and where the spirit quietly bows.

A must-visit for every spiritual traveler, devotee, or seeker of divine peace. Daksheswar Mahadev Temple is not just a destination - it's a divine moment carved into the heart of Haridwar.

Review by @the_solo_wanderer_
For more stories and spiritual travel moments, search me on Instagram. 🌿📸

places.generalDescription: Ganga Aarti Sthal in Haridwar is a vibrant hub of spirituality and devotion, where the sacred Ganges River becomes the backdrop for an enchanting evening ritual. Each night at Har Ki Pauri ghat, priests lead a mesmerizing ceremony filled with light and sound, as they perform prayers using bowls of fire while temple bells resonate through the air. This captivating event draws both tourists and devotees from around the globe who gather to witness this beautiful spectacle.

sources.snippet: Ganga Aarti is a religious prayer offered on the banks of the sacred river Ganga at Haridwar’s Har Ki Pauri ghat. It is a light and sound ceremony that attracts tourists and devotees from all over the world, with priests performing prayers with bowls of fire and the temple bells ringing. Visitors float “diyas” (little candles) and flowers while reciting mantras and reflecting lights off the rushing river, which is supposed to be blessed by the Goddess Ganga.

reviews.text:
Absolutely Divine Experience!
Attending the Ganga Aarti here was one of the most spiritual and mesmerizing moments of my life. The sound of the mantras, the rhythmic clanging of bells, and the sight of hundreds of lamps glowing on the river-it's a moment of peace, energy, and devotion all at once.

Ganga Aarti Sthal, Haridwar
गंगा आरती स्थल, हरिद्वार

A truly divine experience! 🌊✨ The evening Ganga Aarti fills the air with spiritual energy, chants, and the glow of countless diyas. The atmosphere is peaceful yet powerful - a must-visit for anyone seeking serenity, devotion, or a glimpse of India's sacred culture.
Tip: Arrive early to get a good spot and enjoy the full experience. 🙏🪔

Har Ki Pauri is a place on the banks of the Ganga that is spiritually uplifting and has a divine atmosphere, especially during the evening Ganga Aarti. A mystical experience is produced by the sound of chants, the glow of oil lamps, and the movement of the holy river. Be prepared for sizable crowds, particularly on evenings or during festivals. You should be careful with your possessions because the area can get crowded. Although there is room for improvement in terms of cleanliness and infrastructure, the overall spiritual atmosphere makes the trip worthwhile. A Must-See for Spiritual Seekers and Devotees

🎯Ideal Time: Right before bed or in the early morning Aarti ♠️ Advice: If you want peace, stay vigilant in crowded areas and steer clear of busy days.

places.generalDescription: Bharat Mata Temple, located in Haridwar, is a distinctive multi-storey shrine inaugurated by the late Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in 1983. Standing at 180 feet tall with 8 floors, it celebrates India's unity in diversity. Each floor is dedicated to different themes such as Indian heroes, renowned women personalities, saints, and religious harmony. The temple features a unique map of undivided India made from diverse stones and offers mesmerizing views.

sources.snippet: Literally meaning Mother India Temple, Bharat Mata Mandir is a unique multi-storey temple in Haridwar that is dedicated to patriots and freedom fighters. Inaugurated by the late Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in 1983, the 180-feet tall temple with 8 floors celebrates the spirit of unity in diversity, which actually reflects the true essence of our great nation. Each of the eight floors have an individual theme – Bharat Mata dedicated to Mother India, Shoor Mandir dedicated to Indian heroes, Matru Mandir dedicated to renowned women personalities, Sant Mandir dedicated to saints, Assembly Hall reflecting religious harmony, sixth floor dedicated to Goddess Shakti, seventh floor dedicated to Lord Vishnu and eighth floor dedicated to Lord Shiva.

sources.snippet: Bharat Mata Temple has been  a Hindu temple dedicated to the worship of the Hindu goddess Durga, also known as Kali, Shakti or Lalita, located at the southern end of the Har Ki Pauri or Stone Steps in Haridwar, Uttarakhand. The temple features an exquisite marble idol of Durga made by Vishwakarma and enshrined in a dilapidated structure that was built in 1831 by Maharaja Ranjit Singh of the Sikh Empire. Bilvkeshwar Mahadev Mandir in Haridwar is a serene and sacred spot, believed to be where Goddess Parvati performed penance to win Lord Shiva's hand particularly near the Gauri kund 50-60 m away. She used her Kangan to build the Kund. Located just 500–800 m. from Haridwar Junction, the temple is surrounded by lush greenery and forest trails, offering a peaceful atmosphere away from the city crowd. Devotees praise the tranquil vibe, especially in the early mornings. The temple is well-maintained, has no entry fee, and puja items are easily available nearby. Photography inside is generally restricted. It's particularly vibrant during Mahashivratri and the month of Sawan, when devotees flock here for blessings. Some paths through the forest are slightly uneven, which may be challenging for elderlyl or disabled visitors. A unique tradition here is placing layered stone structures (mannat) as a prayer for home-building and fulfillment of personal wishes. Visit is recommended for its spiritual aura, accessibility, and connection to Haridwar's rich religious traditions.
Toilets and water facilities available.

Timings: morning to evening

reviews.text:
Haridwar is also known as Mayapur or Mayapuri and it is referred by this name is most of the ancient Hindu texts. This name is derived from the presence of the Maya Devi temple. If talk about Haridwar everyone tells immediately about Mansa Devi and Chandi Devi temple but very few knows about this temple, which is third peeth of three Siddh Peeths of Haridwar. This temple is located in a more residential area and market near Birla Ghat.

The ancient Maya Devi temple was established in the eleventh century along with The Narayana Shila temple and The Bhairav temple.

Interesting facts about Maya Devi temple:
1. In the main shrine of the temple one can see Maya Devi in the middle, Kali on the left and Kamakhya on the right as per mythology. It is said the heart and navel of Goddess Sati fell at this place. She is considered as the Adhishtadri mean Guardian deity of Haridwar.
2. Pradakshina path around the sanctum sanatorium of the Maya Devi temple has illustrations of the Dasha Mahavidyas which makes it highly importance in follower of Shaktism.
3. During your visit to Maya devi Mandir, you can also visit Anand Bhairav temple which is located in the same premises. Maya Devi and Anand Bhairav shrines are managed by Juna Akhara. There is free meal facility in the Afternoon and Evening.

Temple Visiting Timing:
Morning 06:30 to 12:00
Evening 03:00 to 09:00

Maya Devi Temple is a popular ancient temple in Haridwar and one of Siddh Peeth located in Uttarakhand. Goddess Maya, who is believed to be an incarnation of Goddess Shakti, is the deity of Maya Devi Temple.

Previously Haridwar was known as Mayapuri as Goddess Maya is the diety of Haridwar. Maya Devi Temple also completes the trio of Siddh Peeths in Haridwar. Other two Siddh Peeths in Haridwar are Chandi Devi and Mansa Devi temples.

Inner shrine of the temple has idols of Goddess Maya, Goddess Kali and Goddess Kamakhya. During Navratra and Kumbh Fair devotees in large number visit Maya Devi Temple to take blessings. Maya Devi Temple is located in Har ki Pauri in Haridwar and one can reach here by bus or auto rickshaw. Nearest railway station to reach Maya Devi Temple is Haridwar railway station..

Rajaji National Park – A Hidden Gem of Nature's Majesty

Visiting Rajaji National Park was nothing short of magical. Nestled in the foothills of the Shivalik range near Haridwar, this lesser-known gem offers a perfect blend of wilderness, peace, and raw natural beauty. The dense sal forests, sparkling rivers, and vast grasslands create a breathtaking landscape that immediately puts your soul at ease.

One of the most captivating parts of the park is its rich biodiversity. I was lucky enough to spot elephants, peacocks, deer, and a variety of birds. The sheer thrill of being so close to wildlife in their natural habitat is an experience that stays with you long after you leave. The early morning safari was especially enchanting - mist floating over the riverbed, sunlight piercing through the trees, and the sounds of the forest waking up made it truly unforgettable.

Rajaji is also less crowded compared to other national parks, which means you get to enjoy nature without the noise and chaos of too many tourists. It's the kind of place that reminds you how powerful and peaceful nature can be.

Whether you're a wildlife lover, a nature photographer, or someone looking to escape city life and reconnect with nature, Rajaji National Park is a must-visit. It's not just a destination - it's an experience that fills you with awe and calm.

reviews.text:
Ganga ghats are the region around the river Ganga, Haridwar Is famous for the same and  holy place mentioned in veda script according the Hindu's religious people.it is supposed to be a relaxing place too.
Haridwar as today has not only religious importance but it has another temple of modern civilization i.e. BHEL, a ‘Navratna PSU' to its credit apart from Integrated Industrial Estate(IIE) established at Haridwar under SIIDCUL spread in total area of about 2034 acres. The IIT Roorkee(Earlier Roorkee University) at Roorkee is one of the oldest and prestigious institute of learning in the fields of science and engineering. Another university of the district i.e. Gurukul having vast campus is giving traditional educations of its own kind.
The followers of Lord Shiva(Har) and followers of Lord Vishnu(Hari) pronounce this place Hardwar and Hardwar respectively as told by some. It is also a point of entry to Dev Bhoomi and Char Dham  (Four main centers of pilgrimage in Uttarakhand) Viz.  Badrinath, Kedarnath, Gangotri and Yamunotri.

Legendary king Bhagirath is said to have brought the river Ganga from heaven to earth in order to provide salvation to his ancestors. It is also said that Haridwar has been sanctified by the presence of three Gods; Brahma, Vishnu and Mahesh. Lord Vishnu is said to have his foot print on the stone that is set in the upper wall of Har-Ki-Pauri where the Holy Ganga touches it all the times . Devout believers feel that they can go to heaven by getting their salvation after a dip in the sacred Ganga at Haridwar.

Haridwar is also one of the four places; where Kumbh Mela occurs after rotation of every twelve Years and Ardh Kumbh after every six years. reviews.text:
Nestled on the banks of the Ganga Ghat, this ashram is an ideal sanctuary for meditation and spiritual pursuits, offering a serene environment that fosters inner peace and self-discovery. Established in 1944 by Hans Ji Maharaj, the ashram's origins trace back to a profound moment when he witnessed a snake and a mongoose drinking water together at the Ganga Ghat. Inspired by the harmonious energy of the place, he decided to create an ashram here. Today, the sprawling Prem Ashram is managed by Satpal Maharaj Ji and stands as a testament to its founder's vision.

One of the ashram's highlights is the Govardhan Hall, a massive space dedicated to satsang and meditation. As the largest hall in Asia, it spans 6,000 square meters and features a unique single-span design without supporting columns. Encircled by corridors on all four sides, the hall creates an awe-inspiring sense of vastness, capable of accommodating up to 25,000 people. Stepping inside, one feels as though they have entered a boundless, tranquil space.

Another notable feature is the sacred Panch Pallav tree, where five different trees-vata, pipal, pakar, mango, and gular-grow together from a single base. The leaves of this ancient tree are considered auspicious and are used in religious rituals. Symbolizing the five senses, the five leaves of Pancha Pallav are placed atop a water vessel during puja, representing the divine feminine energy.

The ashram also boasts a stunning Lord Shiva Fountain, which becomes a mesmerizing sight at night when illuminated with multicolored lights. Additionally, the campus includes well-maintained, three-story restroom (toilet) facilities for men and women, a temple, and lush green lawns dotted with numerous trees, including the sacred Rudraksh tree.

Over time, the area surrounding the ashram has transformed into a bustling, upscale neighborhood with various commercial establishments and showrooms of major brands. Situated at the confluence of Jawalapur, Kankhal, and Haridwar, the ashram remains a peaceful retreat amidst the growing urban landscape.

To ensure transparency and prevent fraud, the ashram does not offer online booking for accommodations. Visitors are encouraged to make arrangements directly through the ashram's official channels.

Saptarshi Ashram, located on the serene banks of the Ganges River in Haridwar, is a peaceful sanctuary for spiritual seekers. Known for its rich history and mythology, the ashram is named after the seven great sages (Sapt Rishis) who meditated here. Its tranquil atmosphere and proximity to the holy Ganges create a spiritually charged environment perfect for meditation and self-reflection.

Visitors can participate in yoga and meditation sessions led by experienced practitioners, offering a deep sense of peace and mental clarity. One of the highlights of the ashram is the evening Ganga Aarti, a mesmerizing experience that combines rhythmic mantras, flickering diyas, and the calming flow of the river, providing a truly divine ambiance.

The ashram also hosts spiritual lectures and discourses by renowned saints, offering valuable insights into ancient teachings and modern spirituality. Emphasizing an eco-friendly and simple lifestyle, Saptarshi Ashram provides various accommodation options, from basic rooms to more comfortable choices, catering to all types of visitors.

A dip in the holy Ganges is believed to cleanse the soul, adding to the rejuvenating experience of the ashram. The best time to visit is between October and April when the weather is pleasant. A visit to Saptarshi Ashram is an opportunity to disconnect from the chaos of daily life and connect with the divine in a peaceful, sacred space.

We were in Haridwar on a vacation tour, and that is when we visited the Bhimgoda barrage. The best part was that we got to visit this at Night, and the experience was altogether different seeing this at Night.

The reservoir in itself is vast and is also used for hydroelectricity generation. However, the sheer force of water that you can experience at the actual control point is terrifying. I suggest a must-visit place. And visit the barrage and the control point at Night to have an altogether different experience.

Bhuma Niketan Temple is a serene and spiritually enriching site, nestled along the scenic route of Haridwar's pilgrimage circuit. The temple exudes peace and devotion, offering visitors a tranquil atmosphere away from the bustle of the city. Its architecture is striking, with beautifully carved idols, especially of Lord Shiva and various Hindu deities, which add a vibrant and divine charm to the surroundings.

One thing that stands out is the calm environment and the cleanliness maintained in and around the temple premises. The gentle chants and bhajans playing throughout create a serene experience that's both meditative and welcoming.

What keeps it from being a 5-star spot, however, is that it's slightly less known, so some visitors might miss it if they're not guided properly. Also, it can get crowded during festival times, and facilities like parking or shaded resting areas could be better organized.

Still, Bhuma Niketan is a hidden gem in Haridwar-worth a visit for anyone seeking spiritual comfort and a quiet moment of reflection amid the holy vibes of the city.
